Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: Product Realization 2.0 - Multidisciplinary Technology Entrepreneurship Capstone Course

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) aims to develop a sustainable and scalable model for transforming engineering capstone/senior design courses into an experiential multidisciplinary technology entrepreneurship capstone course, Product Realization 2.0 that is strongly coupled with co-curricular or extra-curricular student entrepreneurial programs (campus wide) and powered by regional industry partners. The Product Realization course was initially designed to give students real world, project-based experience while offering industry sponsors access to engineering talent and innovative solutions. This project will explore whether or not stakeholders (including students and sponsors) will find value in a structure that trains students and exposes industry sponsors to a broader set of entrepreneurial thinking skills. The project is moving towards a course that will have the following key curricular elements: (a) customer discovery and lean launch, (b) design thinking, and (c) product design with an emphasis on low-resolution prototyping and multiple iterations. The course would have to have another dimension: professional development for sponsor-mentors. We will explore various levels of mentor engagement and training, ranging from straightforward project management processes to incorporating mentors into a teaching team.

The Product Realization course can contribute significantly to innovation in engineering and multidisciplinary education, will promote new curricula and pedagogy, and will provide a platform for engaging students and sponsors in a different way. The product has potential appeal to regional industry and can connect with an innovation and entrepreneurship experiential curriculum at UWM. Through various innovation networks, such as the I-Corps Site regional network of five universities, the National Innovation Network, Pathways to Innovation Network and University Innovation Fellows Network, the proposed model can be scaled up nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed at developing a sustainable and scalable model for transforming engineering capstone/senior design courses into an experiential multidisciplinary technology entrepreneurship capstone course, Product Realization 2.0, that would be strongly coupled with co-curricular or extra-curricular student entrepreneurial programs (campus wide) and powered by regional industry partners. 

The Product Realization course was initially designed to give students real world, project-based experience while offering industry sponsors access to engineering talent and innovative solutions; we watned to explore whether or not stakeholders (including students and sponsors) would find value in a structure that trains students and exposes industry sponsors to a broader set of entrepreneurial thinking skills.

We wanted to move towards a course that would have the following key curricular elements: (a) customer discovery and lean launch, (b) design thinking, and (c) product design with an emphasis on low-resolution prototyping and multiple iterations. The course would have to have another dimension: professional development for sponsor-mentors.

We wanted to explore various levels of mentor engagement and training, ranging from straightforward project management processes to incorporating mentors into a teaching team.

Getting outside the building - we have conducted more than 100 customer discovery interviews with:

  • Engineering managers/directors (16)
  • Humar resource managers (25)
  • Corporate leadership (6)
  • External recruiters (4)
  • Engineers (13)
  • Interns in engineering firms (7)
  • Engineering students (2)
  • Instructors of capstone courses (10)
  • Career service directors in academia (6)
  • Academic leadership/administration (7)

The key objective was to test our business model built around the initial concept of a University-industry collaborative platform for entrepreneurial experiential learning and open innovation. 

This is what we have learned:

  • It’s not about the project, it’s all about Engineering Manager/Director geting the talent (22/29 engineers)
  • Development of talent within the organization wasn't a pain point (38/44 managers)
  • The focus of discovery has to be shifted from engineering- to HR managers who most keenly feel the pain...and who would pay for our product.
  • Recruiting and training budgets are spread across the organizational units (4/7 large companies).
  • Matrix decision making: buy-in from multiple stakeholders to sell the idea to VP leader with budget authority.
  • There is pain and money in finding the right hires (22/28 HR managers).
  • For inexperienced hires, companies place a high value on a professor recommendation (34/44 hiring managers) - but it is not scalable.
  • Everybody in engineering companies want to address diversity problem, but nobody has a great solution (35/48 engineering- and HR managers).
  • Everybody hates career fairs (22/28 HR managers, students and hiring managers).
  • Getting the first internship is the hardest (6/9 engineering students).
  • Demonstrated skills are valuable to companies ... and students (20/32 HR and engineering managers).

Based on the evidence, the value proposition of our business model has changed to:

"We help engineering companies identify talent, and students get their first internship, through a sponsored experiential interview that demonstrates targeted skills." 

The minimum viable product - an experiential interview - would consist of two parts:

  1. Curriculum for an experiential interview (team-based design challenge for prospective hires)
  2. Live resume annotation / skill assessment software platform
